rate: Based on the data, the Bank of England appears relatively more dovish, having cut rates to 4.25% in May, while the Federal Reserve held steady at 4.5%. inflation:
UK inflation slowed in March 2025, with CPI at 2.6% and core at 3.4%. US inflation also eased, with PCE at 2.3% and core PCE at 2.6%.

Comparing the data, UK inflation pressures appear stronger, particularly in core measures (3.4% vs US 2.6%). This suggests the Bank of England faces more persistent inflation risk than the Federal Reserve, whose preferred measure (PCE) is closer to target.

Consequently, the BoE may be slower to cut rates than the Fed. This relative divergence in rate path expectations is fundamentally supportive for GBP/USD.
growth:

This highlights a clear divergence, with US momentum decelerating while the UK shows signs of stabilization or modest improvement. The relative macro momentum favors GBP over USD. This divergence in growth outlook suggests potential upward pressure on the GBP/USD pair.
